At that time, Earth was just beginning to develop multicellular life. The narrative transitions to the present, highlighting the pioneering work of scientists Rai Weiss, Kip Thorne, and Ronald Drever, who faced initial skepticism in their efforts to construct the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) to detect these gravitational waves. Their project ultimately gained support from the US National Science Foundation and led to significant advancements, culminating in the activation of Advanced LIGO. A historic milestone was achieved on September 14, 2015, when LIGO successfully detected gravitational waves from the black hole collision. 

The summary also includes a personal reflection from theoretical physicist Scott Hughes, who discusses the emotional and scientific significance of gravitational waves in a conversation with Allan Adams. Hughes connects pivotal moments in his life—his daughter's birth and the farewell to his terminally ill father—to his scientific achievements. He explains that gravitational waves are ripples in space and time that stretch and compress everything they encounter, emphasizing the challenges researchers face at LIGO in detecting these extremely weak waves, which require precise measurements on a minuscule scale. The historical context of gravitational wave research is further highlighted with a quote from Kip Thorne regarding the technical difficulties involved, while Adams metaphorically describes LIGO as functioning more like an ear than an eye, underscoring its role in sensing these elusive waves. Zwei schwarze Löcher mit 29 und 36 Sonnenmassen drehten sich 100 Mal pro Sekunde umeinander, bevor sie kollidierten. LIGO ermöglicht es, das Universum zu "hören" und das Unsichtbare zu erfassen, da Gravitationswellen durchdringen Materie, die für Licht undurchlässig ist, und uns Einblicke in das frühe Universum sowie unerforschte Phänomene geben könnten. Der Klang, den LIGO am 14. September 2015 aufnahm, zeigt, wie Gravitationswellen Informationen über kosmische Ereignisse liefern können. LIGO hat bereits unerwartete Entdeckungen gemacht, die unser Verständnis der Entstehung von Sternen und der Geschichte des Universums erweitern. Matt Evans von der LIGO-Kollaboration vergleicht die beobachteten schwarzen Löcher mit Dinosaurierknochen, die wertvolle Informationen über die Vergangenheit des Universums liefern. Die Herausforderung besteht darin, mutig und innovativ in der Erforschung des Universums zu sein.
